Graphical abstract The development of efficient catalysts with high selectivity is a major challenge for propane dehydrogenation (PDH), which is an on-purpose route to produce propylene. We have developed a high-throughput computational strategy to screen out the promising catalysts for propane dehydrogenation to propylene on Cu-based metal alloys. A total of 1500 candidates of Cu3M1 alloys are constructed, and four efficient descriptors are applied in our high-throughput screening to evaluate the activity and selectivity of catalysts. Four Cu-based alloys of Cu3Cr1, Cu3Pd1, Cu3Pt1, and Cu3Ag1 are identified as promising PDH catalysts, and their superior selectivity towards propylene could be explained by the synergistic effect of Cu and M atoms. Our theoretical screening method could assist the new catalyst design and accelerate the discovery of environment-friendly alloy catalysts for PDH. Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Propylene is one of the most important feedstocks for the manufacture of many highly valued products, such as acetone, phenol, polypropylene, and propylene oxide [1,2], and the supply of propylene is struggling to meet the growing global demand. Propane dehydrogenation (PDH), an on-purpose propylene production technology, is regarded as the promising route due to the growing accessibility of propane extracted from shale gas. Until now, Pt catalysts have been widely used in industrial PDH processes owing to their excellent activation for C–H bonds, but as a high-selectivity PDH catalyst, it is also hindered by significant challenges, including rapid deactivation due to sintering and coke deposition with deep dehydrogenation, as well as the high cost of production[3–5]. Specifically, enhancing the selectivity of the propylene with easy desorption is crucial for subsequent applications. In contrast, although Cu catalysts exhibit resistance to coking and sintering, their activity in PDH is limited due to the high energy barrier for C–H bond activation [6–8]. Therefore, it is urgent to probe the high-efficient catalysts for PDH with both activity and selectivity. Metal alloys generally exhibit unique properties, different from their parent metals, which are extensively employed in the development of novel catalysts with improved catalytic performance [9–16]. Using this strategy, numerous studies have been conducted to enhance the catalytic performance of Pt catalysts for PDH. For example, Bariås et al. [17] reported that Pt-Sn alloys have much higher selectivity to propylene than Pt-only catalysts. Chen et al. [18] also proved that the introduction of Sn atoms into Pt weakens the adsorption of propylene thus enhancing the PDH selectivity from theoretical calculations. Subsequently, many efforts have been made to modulate the surface structure of Pt-M alloys to improve the PDH performance, such as Pt-Fe [19,20], Pt-Co [21], Pt-Zn [22,23], Pt-Cu [24], PtGa [25], and Pt-In [26]. Gong et al. [27] have theoretically studied the PDH reaction over various Pt-M alloys, demonstrating that the activity will decline with the rise of selectivity. Miller et al. [28] have reported that the Pt3Mn displays a relatively high selectivity of propylene, which is attributed to the reduced binding energies. Recently, Sykes et al. [6] proposed that the Rh atoms dispersed in Cu could result in low C–H bond activation barriers, strengthening the sintering resistance and boosting PDH activity in contrast to Pt-based catalysts. More recently, Zhang et al. [29] have systematically evaluated the stability, PDH activity and selectivity on metal-incorporated Ni3M alloys, and demonstrated that the incorporation of V and Nb metals could generate unique Ni-M cooperative sites, thus improving catalytic performance. Nevertheless, the catalytic mechanism of Cu-based alloy catalysts for PDH reaction has not been systematically investigated, and further understanding will accelerate the development of the novel catalysts. In this work, we conduct a comprehensive theoretical screening for Cu3M1 (M=3d metals, 4d metals, 5d metals and Al, Ga, Ge, In, Sn) by using high-throughput density functional theory (DFT) calculations. About 1500 Cu3M1 alloy structures are considered and their PDH activity is extensively evaluated. Four key descriptors are employed to describe the catalytic PDH performance, and Cu3Cr1, Cu3Pd1, Cu3Pt1 and Cu3Ag1 are finally identified as the superior catalysts for selective propane dehydrogenation to propylene. Our results have confirmed the synergistic effect of Cu and M atoms in alloys, which facilitates the selective dehydrogenation reaction. Our high-throughput computational method provides an efficient way to screen out the metal alloy catalysts for PDH reaction with significant potential for future industrial applications. 2 Computational method All the DFT calculations are performed by the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [30]. The projected augmented wave (PAW) method [31] is used to describe the electron–ion interactions. The exchange–correlation potential is described by the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) based on the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [32]. The cutoff energy is set to 400 eV for the plane wave basis and the vacuum space was set to 20 Å to avoid the interlayer interaction. Since the adsorption energy of n-alkanes predicted by DFT-D3 agrees well with the experiments, here we use it to describe the vdW interaction [33,34]. Transition state searches are performed using the climbing image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) method [35]. The convergence criteria of force and energy on structural optimization and CI-NEB calculations are set to be 0.05 eV Å−1 and 10-4 eV, respectively. A 2 × 2 × 2 supercell of Cu crystal containing 32 atoms is used as the initial structural model. To construct Cu3M1 alloys, we have randomly substituted 8 Cu atoms with M atoms (M=3d metals, 4d metals, 5d metals and Al, Ga, Ge, In, Sn). More than 1500 alloy structures (50 different configurations for each Cu3M1) are generated for further optimization. After identifying the Cu3M1 structures with the lowest formation energy ( Figure S1 ), we further optimize their lattice parameters and cleave the Cu3M1 (111) surface. As shown in Figure S3 , the (111) surface is composed of alternating a and b layers, resulting in two different types of Cu3M1 (111) surfaces, denoted as “Cu3M1-a” and “Cu3M1-b”, which exhibit different terminations of surface with Cu and M atoms. The √ 3 × √ 3 supercell of Cu3M1(111) surface is utilized to calculate the PDH reaction, with the thickness of four atomic layers and the bottom two layers are fixed. The workflow of the high-throughput screening is plotted in Fig. 1 . To verify the structural stability of Cu3M1 alloys, the formation energy ( E f o r m ) is defined as follows [36]: (1) E f o r m = ( E C u 3 M 1 - 24 E C u - 8 E M ) / 32 where E C u 3 M 1 is the total energy of the Cu3M1 alloy, and E C u / E M represents the energy of a Cu or M atom in its bulk phase. The surface energy ( E s u r f ) of Cu3M1 alloy surfaces is determined according to the following equation [37]: (2) E s u r f = ( E s l a b u n r e l a x - n E b u l k ) / 2 A + ( E s l a b r e l a x - E s l a b u n r e l a x ) / A where E s l a b r e l a x and E s l a b u n r e l a x are the energies of the relaxed and unrelaxed surfaces, respectively, E b u l k represents the energy of a unit in the bulk phase, A is the surface area, and n is the number of formula units in the slab. The adsorption energy ( E a d C 3 H 8 ) of propane is calculated by [38,39]: (3) E a d C 3 H 8 = E s u r f a c e + C 3 H 8 - E s u r f a c e - E C 3 H 8 where E s u r f a c e + C 3 H 8 and E s u r f a c e are the total energies of alloy surfaces with and without the propane adsorption, respectively. E C 3 H 8 is the total energy of propane in the gas phase. The desorption energy ( E d e s C 3 H 6 ) of propylene is calculated by [40]: (4) E d e s C 3 H 6 = E s u r f a c e + E C 3 H 6 - E s u r f a c e + C 3 H 6 where E s u r f a c e + C 3 H 6 and E s u r f a c e are the total energies of alloy surfaces with and without the adsorption of propylene, respectively. E C 3 H 6 is the total energy of propylene in the gas phase. 3 Results and discussion The structural stability of these Cu-based alloys is evaluated by the formation energy, and a more negative value indicates higher stability. As previous reports suggest [41,42], the alloys with a formation energy of less than 0.20 eV are considered potentially stable. As shown in Fig. 2 a, the structural stability of Cu3M1 alloy gradually decreases with the doping of M elements from ⅣB to ⅥB group. When the introduced M atoms vary from ⅦB to ⅢA group, the formation energies progressively become negative, indicating the increased thermodynamic stability, such as Al and Pd with the formation energies of −0.15 eV and −0.08 eV, respectively. Due to the strong inter-atomic repulsion, the doping of metal atoms with Sc, Y, Zr, In, Sn, and Hf leads to the large structural deformation in Cu-based crystals, so these alloys are excluded in our following calculations ( Figure S1 ). To confirm the structural stablity of Cu3M1 alloys, we have compared the randomly doped structures and the M−segregated configurations, as shown in Figure S2 . Our proposed Cu3M1 alloys possess relatively lower energies than those of the phase-separated structures. Considering two different terminations for each alloy, 46 surfaces are obtained and relaxed. The surface energies of all surfaces are calculated and shown in Table S1 and Figure S3 , except for Cu3M1 (M=Al, Mn, Ga, Ge) with obvious surface reconstructions ( Figure S4 ). Most of Cu3M1 surfaces exhibit comparable surface energies to pure Cu (111) surface and lower than those of Ni3M1 alloy surfaces (1.55 ∼ 2.47 J/m2) [29], proving that the surfaces of these alloys could be easily formed. Finally, 19 kinds of Cu3M1 alloys (38 alloy surfaces) are screened out for further evaluation on the PDH activity. Scheme 1 shows the possible reactions involved in PDH. First, propane is adsorbed on the catalyst surface, and then dehydrogenated into *CH3CH2CH2 (R1) or *CH3CHCH3 (R2) depending on which C–H bond breaks first. Subsequently, the intermediates are further dehydrogenated into propylene (R4), which is our desired product. However, there are also side reactions with the generation of *CH3CH2CH (R3) or CH3CCH3 (R5). Finally, propylene can either desorb from the catalyst surface or undergo deep dehydrogenation into *CH3CCH2 (R6) and *CH3CHCH (R7). Followed by these reaction paths, we have systematically evaluated the activity and selectivity of PDH reaction on Cu3M1 surfaces by four key descriptors, and screened out the promising catalysts for propylene production with high selectivity. Following the PDH reaction paths, the first reaction step is the propane adsorption, so the first descriptor to evaluate the PDH activity is the adsorption energy of propane ( E a d C 3 H 8 ). On Cu3M1 alloy surface, there are some inequivalent sites for the propane adsorption due to the inhomogeneous distribution of M atoms. We have considered the possible adsorption sites near the M atoms and determined the optimal site of propane adsorption on different Cu3M1 surfaces ( Figures S5 ). The adsorption energies corresponding to the most energetically favorable sites are plotted in Fig. 2 b. On Cu (111) surface, the adsorption energy for propane is calculated to be −0.57 eV. After doping by the additional metal atoms, the adsorption energies could be modulated from −0.48 eV to −1.26 eV. As shown in Figure S6 , a linear relationship between the adsorption energy and d-band center of active metal site is found, and a more positive d-band value exhibits a stronger adsorption strength towards propane. As the d-band center shifts from −0.93 eV (Cu3Ru1) to −0.57 eV (Cu3Ti1), the adsorption energy of propane increases from −0.69 eV to −0.92 eV. The 19 kinds of Cu3M1 alloys (36 different surfaces) show moderate adsorption energies for propane (−0.40 eV∼−1.00 eV), which are selected for further investigations. To achieve the high selectivity of propylene product, the desorption energy of propylene ( E d e s C 3 H 6 ) is used as the second descriptor for screening out the catalysts. Fig. 3 a plots the desorption energies of propylene on different Cu3M1 surfaces. As the dopant metal varies from left to right in the same elemental period, the desorption energy gradually decreases. For example, the calculated desorption energies are 2.34 eV for Cu3Ta1, 1.76 eV for Cu3Os1, and 1.57 eV for Cu3Pt1, respectively. Propylene can easily desorb from Cu3Ag1, Cu3Au1 and Cu3Zn1 surfaces with the desorption energies of less than 1 eV, especially for Cu3Zn1 with the lowest desorption energy of 0.59 eV, which is greatly lower than those on the recently reported Ni3Zn1 (1.42 eV) and Ni3V1 (1.47 eV) alloys [29]. For the other alloy catalysts, the desorption of propylene is relatively difficult ( > 1 eV). To explain the desorption behavior of propylene, we calculated and compared the desorption energies of propylene on M and Cu sites for these Cu3M1 surfaces, as shown in Fig. 3 b. The desorption energies of propylene on Cu site are reasonably smaller than those on M site, for example, on Cu3Pt1, the desorption energy decreases from 1.39 to 0.87 eV with the site changes from M to Cu sites, suggesting propylene shows a preference for adsorption on the M sites over the Cu sites. Furthermore, the migration barriers for propylene from M to Cu sites are calculated and summarized in Fig. 3 c and Table S2 . The small migration barrier confirms that the diffusion of propylene is a virtually barrierless process, thus the desorption rate of propylene on these surfaces will be equivalent either directly from the M site or via migrating to the Cu site. Here, twenty kinds of alloy surfaces with relatively larger desorption barriers ( > 1.50 eV) are excluded. Moreover, the desorption energy of C3H6 shows a strong correlation with the d-band center (Fig. 3 d), and the desorption of propylene becomes difficult as the d-band center is closer to the Femi level. As the high selectivity PDH catalyst, propylene desorption on surface should be easier than its deep dehydrogenation, so we define the energy difference ( E d i f f ) to further estimate the selectivity of Cu3M1 catalysts by the following equation: (5) E d i f f = E d e e p - E des C 3 H 6 where E d e e p indicates the barrier of deep dehydrogenation for propylene, and E des C 3 H 6 is the desorption energy of propylene on M site for these alloys. The positive values of E d i f f indicate the relatively high selectivity of propylene product, and the negative values reflect the relatively low selectivity of propylene. As shown in Fig. 4 a-b, propylene desorption plays a critical role in determining E d i f f , for example, the larger propylene desorption energy of 1.49 eV results in more negative E d i f f value of −1.11 eV on Cu3Ru1, which indicates propylene will be further dehydrogenated. Screened by this descriptor, six Cu3M1 alloys (M=Cr, Zn, Pd, Ag, Pt, and Au) are identified as the potential catalysts for PDH with high selectivity of propylene instead of deep hydrogenation. The first C–H activation for propane is usually the rate-determining step for PDH reaction, so the activation barrier ( E B a r r i e r C - H ) is taken into account as the fourth descriptor to screen out promising catalysts (Fig. 4 c). The Cu3M1 alloys (M=Zn and Au) exhibit a difficult ability to break the C–H bond, such as 1.49 eV for Cu3Au1. The incorporation of Cr, Pd, and Pt atoms induces efficient C–H activation, with the relatively low barriers of 0.83 eV on Cu3Cr1, 0.93 eV on Cu3Pd1, and 1.13 eV on Cu3Pt1, respectively. As depicted in Fig. 4 d, the activation barrier of C–H bond in propane is closely associated with the adsorption strength of propane, and the appropriate adsorption energy (−0.56 eV∼−0.76 eV) could effectively facilitate the first C–H activation for propane. Based on the above four descriptors, we have screened out four promising candidates for catalytic PDH reaction, and they are Cu3Cr1, Cu3Pd1, Cu3Pt1 and Cu3Ag1. To validate the accuracy of our descriptors, the whole PDH reaction processes are calculated by taking Cu3Pd1 and Cu3Ag1 as the representatives. As shown in Scheme 1, starting from propane, there are two possible pathways to produce propylene (Path 1: R2 → R4 and Path 2: R1 → R4). On Cu3Ag1 surface, the activation barrier to generate *CH3CHCH3 is calculated to be 1.14 eV by breaking the middle C–H bond, lower than the barrier for the end C–H cleavage to form *CH3CH2CH2 (1.26 eV), and then it overcomes another barrier of 0.67 eV to obtain propylene, so the Cu3Ag1 catalyst follows path 1 of PDH reaction (Fig. 5 ). Similarly, on Cu3Pd1 surface, the generation of propylene also follows path 1 with the activation barriers of 0.93 eV for the first C–H bond cleavage to form *CH3CHCH3, and further need to overcome another barrier of 0.70 eV for the second C–H bond cleavage to produce propylene, respectively. All the barriers are remarkably lower than those on pure Cu surface (1.31 eV) and comparable to the reported Pt3M (0.65 ∼ 0.93 eV) and Ni3M (0.72 ∼ 1.38 eV) catalysts [43], demonstrating the superior PDH performance. Furthermore, the production of propylene is accompanied by the side reaction R5, and our results have shown that the barriers in forming *CH3CCH3 (1.66 eV for Cu3Pd1 and 1.21 eV for Cu3Ag1) are all greatly larger than the activation barriers of propylene formation (R4), so the side reactions are efficiently suppressed. After the formation of propylene, the deep dehydrogenation of propylene (R6 and R7) has a negative effect on the catalyst selectivity. If the dehydrogenation of propylene is favored over its formation and desorption, deep dehydrogenation is possible to occur. Our calculations present that the deep dehydrogenation barriers for propylene are all larger than the formation and desorption of propylene, they are 1.64 eV (R6) and 1.47 eV (R7) for Cu3Pd1 as well as 1.43 eV (R6) and 1.33 eV (R7) for Cu3Ag1, respectively, so the deep dehydrogenation could be also effectively inhibited. These Cu-based alloy catalysts exhibit better selectivity performance than Pt-based and Ni-based catalysts [43], with easier desorption and more difficult deep dehydrogenation of propylene. To further understand the insight into the efficient conversion of propane to propylene, the projected density of states (PDOS) is calculated. As shown in Fig. 6 a-b, for Cu3Ag1, the peaks of Cu 3d orbitals appear near the Fermi level, indicating the Cu sites are preferred to interact with adsorbates. On the surface of Cu3Pd1, the decrease of Cu 3d states and increase of Pd 4d states in the region from −4 eV to 0 eV demonstrate that the doping of Pd could greatly modify the electronic structures. Additionally, the Pd 4d orbitals shift to the Fermi level, suggesting the surface Pd sites are therefore the adsorption sites for reaction intermediates, which could be responsible for the enhanced binding strength of propane and propylene as well as superior PDH activity. To understand the high selectivity for propylene products, the projected crystal orbital Hamilton population (pCOHP) is also employed [44], which is plotted in Fig. 6 c. On Cu3Pd1 surface, the calculated integrated COHP (ICOHP) values between Pd and two C atoms are −0.17 and −0.17, respectively, while the ICOHP values decrease to −0.01 and −0.02 after the migration of propylene to Cu site. This demonstrates that the electron occupations in antibonding orbitals relative to those in bonding orbitals are increased on the Cu site in Cu3Pd1, resulting in relatively weaker Cu-C bonds and easier desorption of propylene. For Cu3Ag1, the PDH reaction occurs on Cu site, and the calculated ICOHP are as low as −0.08 and −0.10, respectively, confirming a similar weaker binding strength. Therefore, the M metal facilitates the activation of C–H in propane, and the Cu atoms promote the desorption of propylene. This synergistic effect in Cu3M1 surface remarkably improves the catalytic performance. 4 Conclusion In summary, we have performed high-throughput computations to discover promising Cu-based alloy catalysts for selective propane dehydrogenation into propylene. Four efficient descriptors have been used to evaluate the activity and selectivity of PDH reaction, and four alloys (Cu3Cr1, Cu3Pd1, Cu3Pt1 and Cu3Ag1) are screened out as the promising catalysts with satisfactory activity and selectivity, which are finally validated by the whole PDH reaction calculations. They exhibit lower desorption barriers for propylene and higher barriers for deep dehydrogenation of propylene, which are superior to pure Cu surface and most Ni-based catalysts. The electronic analysis has also revealed that the synergistic effect of Cu and M atoms in Cu-based alloys facilitates the selective dehydrogenation reaction. The M atoms weaken the C–H bond in propane, while the Cu atoms facilitate the desorption of propylene and effectively inhibit the propylene from deep dehydrogenation. Our computational screening method incorporating both activity and selectivity criteria guides the exploration of multi-metallic compounds that go beyond the limitations of conventional single-metal catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The development of efficient catalysts with high selectivity is a major challenge for propane dehydrogenation (PDH), which is an on-purpose route to produce propylene. We have developed a high-throughput computational strategy to screen out the promising catalysts for propane dehydrogenation to propylene on Cu-based metal alloys. A total of 1500 candidates of Cu3M1 alloys are constructed, and four efficient descriptors are applied in our high-throughput screening to evaluate the activity and selectivity of catalysts. Four Cu-based alloys of Cu3Cr1, Cu3Pd1, Cu3Pt1, and Cu3Ag1 are identified as promising PDH catalysts, and their superior selectivity towards propylene could be explained by the synergistic effect of Cu and M atoms. Our theoretical screening method could assist the new catalyst design and accelerate the discovery of environment-friendly alloy catalysts for PDH.
